abstract.text: Rare heavy flavor decays provide stringent tests of the Standard Model of particle physics and allow to test for possible new Physics scenarios.
The LHCb experiment at CERN is the ideal place for these searches as it has recorded the worlds largest sample of beauty mesons.
The status of the rare decay analyses with 1 fb −1 of √ s = 7 TeV of ppcollisions collected by the LHCb experiment in 2011 is reviewed.
The worlds most precise measurements of the angular structure of B 0 → K * 0 µ + µ − decays is discussed, as well as the isospin asymmetry measurement in B → K ( * ) µ + µ − decays.
The most stringent upper exclusion limit on the branching fraction of B 0 s → µ + µ − decays is shown, as well as searches for lepton number and lepton flavor violating processes.

body_text.text: Introduction
Rare processes which proceed via flavor changing neutral currents (FCNC) are forbidden at tree level in the Standard Model (SM).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: They can proceed via loop level electroweak (Z 0 , γ) penguin or box diagrams.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In extensions to the SM, new virtual particles can enter at loop level, modifying the amplitude of the process or the Lorentz structure of the decay vertex.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Possible deviations from the SM predictions on branching fractions or angular distributions could lead to the discovery of physics beyond the SM.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This article reviews some of the most sensitive probes for possible extensions of the Standard Model that were measured by the LHCb collaboration with a dataset of 1 fb −1 of √ s = 7 TeV of pp-collisions collected in 2011.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An angular analysis of B 0 → K * 0 µ + µ − decays 2 allows a stringent test of the Lorentz structure of the electroweak penguin process and is particularly sensitivity to right-handed currents.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The measurement of the decay rate of B 0 s,d → µ + µ − decays are highly sensitive to scalar and pseudoscalar currents, which are non-existent in the SM.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The article closes with a discussion of searches for lepton number and lepton flavor violation and B-hadron and τ ± -lepton decays.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The rare decay processes presented here provide a complementary approach to direct searches at the general purpose detectors and can give sensitivity to new particles at higher mass scales than those accessible directly.

body_text.text: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays
A search for Majorana neutrinos with a mass of O(1 GeV) can be made in lepton number violating (LNV) B and D meson decays.
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: These indirect searches are performed by analysing the decay rate of processes as B + → π − µ + µ + [20,21].
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: These same sign di-leptonic decays can only occur via exchange of heavy Majorana neutrinos.
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: Resonant production may be possible if the heavy neutrino is kinematically accessible, which could put the rates of these decays within reach of the present or future LHCb luminosity.
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: Alternatively, limits on these LNV processes, together with low energy neutrino data, results in better constraints for neutrino masses and mixing parameters in models with extended neutrino sectors.
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: Using 0.4 fb −1 of integrated luminosity from LHCb, limits have been set on the branching fraction of B + → D − (s) µ + µ + decays at the level of a few times 10 −7 and on B + → π − µ + µ + at the level of 1 × 10 −8 [22,23].
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: These branching fraction limits imply a limit on the coupling |V µ4 | between ν µ and a Majorana neutrino with a mass in the range 1 < m N < 4 GeV/c 2 of |V µ4 | 2 < 5 × 10 −5 .
body_text.section: Searches for an Majorana neutrinos in B decays

body_text.text: Search for lepton flavor violation in
Lepton flavor violating (LFV) τ − decays are forbidden in the classical SM and are vanishing small after the extension of the SM with neutrino mixing.
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: Many New Physics models predict enhancements, up to observable values which are close to the current experimental bounds.
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: The neutrinoless decay τ − → µ + µ − µ − is a particular sensitive mode in which to search for LFV at LHCb as the experimental signature with the three muon final state is very clean.
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: The inclusive τ − production crosssection at LHCb is very large, about 80 µb.
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: The composition of the τ − production can be calculated from the bb and cc [24] cross-sections measured at the LHCb experiment and the inclusive branching ratios b → τ and c → τ [25].
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: About 80% of the produced τ − -leptons originate from D − s decays.
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: LHCb has performed a search for the decay τ − → µ + µ − µ − using 1.0 fb −1 of data [26].
body_text.section: Search for lepton flavor violation in

body_text.text: The upper limit on the branching fraction was found to be B(τ − → µ + µ − µ − ) < 7.8 (6.3) × 10 −8 at 95 % (90 %) C.L, to be compared with the current best experimental upper limit from the Belle collaboration: B(τ − → µ + µ − µ − ) < 2.1×10 −8 at 90 % C.L. As the data sample increases this limit is expected to scale with the square root of the luminosity, with possible further reduction depending on improvements in the analysis.

body_text.text: The large integrated luminosity that will be collected by the upgraded LHCb experiment will provide a sensitivity corresponding to an upper limit of a few times 10 −9 [27].

body_text.text: Conclusion
Most scenarios of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics predict measurable effects in the flavor sector, in particular in rare B meson decays.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: No sign of physics beyond the Standard Model has yet been observed and stringent limits on its scale have been set.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Sensitive probes for NP are the leptonic decays B 0 s,d → µ + µ − and the rare electroweak penguin decay B 0 → K * 0 µ + µ − .
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The most recent measurements performed by the LHCb collaboration in these two modes are in good agreement with SM predictions and set strong constraints on possible extensions of the SM.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The isospin asymmetry in the decays B → K ( * ) µ + µ − has been measured by several experiments.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: These measurements agree with each other and with SM predictions for the decays with a K * 0 , but there is a significant tension with respect to expectations for the decays with a kaon.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Precise calculations are needed to interpret this tension.
